subclassFeatures: Way of the Feral Warrior|Monk||Feral Warrior|LLMT|3

subclass.name: Way of the Sacred Ink
subclassFeatures: Way of the Sacred Ink|Monk||Sacred Ink|LLMT|3

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Boulder
entries: The Way of the Boulder is a tradition as old as the mountains themselves. Dwelling in secluded monasteries on high mountain peaks and deep in subterranean caverns, monks of this tradition focus on becoming as large and immovable as the mountains that surround them. They seek to grow in girth and size, and use their weight to land devastating blows in combat.

As a practitioner of the Way of the Boulder, you seek to become solid like diamond, imposing like a jagged mountain peak, unmoving like the bedrock of the earth, and fruitful like fertile soil. Boulder monks are often stubborn and inflexible in their thinking, and take a great deal of time to come to a decision. But once won over to your cause, they will stand by your side no matter the dangers you must face.

subclassFeature.name: Solid Body
entries: Upon adopting this monastic tradition at 3rd level, you learn to use your physical bulk to enhance your defenses and empower your strikes. When not wearing armor or using a shield your armor class is equal to 10 + your Constitution modifier + your Wisdom modifier. You can also use your Constitution, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes or with a monk weapon. However, your great girth has made you slower then most other monks. The bonus to your speed you gain from your Unarmored Movement feature is reduced by half.

In addition, you have learned to use your ki to reinforce your robust frame. As a bonus action, you can spend one ki point to grant yourself advantage on all Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks until the beginning of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Rebounding Defense
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your massive body to absorb or reflect all but the most powerful blows. As a reaction, when you are hit by a melee weapon attack, you can spend 1 ki point to reduce the damage by an amount equal to {@dice 1d12} + your Constitution modifier + your monk level.

If you reduce the damage of the attack to 0, you can use your great girth to rebound the attack back at the attacker. If you stop an attack in this way, you make a melee weapon attack as part of the same reaction. You make this attack with proficiency, regardless of your weapon proficiencies, and it counts as a monk weapon for the purposes of this attack.

subclassFeature.name: Thick Fat
entries: Beginning at 11th level, your dense physical form lets you resist physical as well as elemental assaults. When you finish a short or long rest, you choose one of the following damage types: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing, acid, cold, fire, poison, lighting, or thunder. You are resistant to that type of damage until the end of your next short or long rest.
As a bonus action, you can spend 2 ki points to switch the damage resistance you gained from this ability to another damage resistance from the list above.

subclassFeature.name: Mighty Form
entries: Upon reaching 17th level your body has surpassed the normal mortal limits of density and mass. Your Constitution score, and maximum Constitution score, both increase by 2.

In addition, you can use your immense bulk to shake the world around you. As an action you expend 3 ki points and stomp ground beneath your feet. The ground in a 15-foot radius around you becomes difficult terrain and creatures of your choice within the 15-foot radius must make a Strength saving throw. Creatures take {@dice 2d10} bludgeoning damage and fall {@condition prone} on a failed save. On a successful save they take half damage and don't fall {@condition prone}.
When you use this feature, you can expend additional ki points, increasing the damage of your stomp by {@dice 1d10} for each additional ki point, to a maximum of {@dice 10d10}.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Feral Warrior
entries: Monks of all traditions seek to gain physical mastery over themselves and in the process these spiritual warriors hone their flesh into a potent weapon. However, creatures born with natural weapons; vicious claws, imposing horns, and hardened scales, have an advantage other monks don't

These creatures of bestial heritage follow the Way of the Feral Warrior. They hone their imposing natural features into deadly weapons, and train to master the primal ferocity that dwells within their blood.

subclassFeature.name: Optional Rule: Race Restriction
entries: The Way of the Feral Warrior is typically practiced by creatures of bestial ancestry. In my home setting, only creatures with natural weapon attacks can choose this Monastic Tradition, but your DM can lift that restriction to better suit the campaign.

subclassFeature.name: Fist of Scale & Bone
entries: Your body itself evolved to be a weapon. Whether it be claws, teeth, spines, or scales, your physical form has innate combat potential. Starting at 3rd level your Martial Arts damage die increases to a {@dice d6} for your unarmed strikes.
The size of your Martial Arts die for your unarmed strikes increases as you gain levels in this class; to {@dice 1d8} at 5th level, {@dice 1d10} at 11th level, and {@dice 1d12} at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Predator
entries: Upon adopting this Monastic Tradition at 3rd level, you enhance your natural ability with a discipline of your choice from the options listed below. Most creatures adopt the discipline that aligns with their heritage, but the disciplines of this tradition can be mastered by anyone without restriction.

entries.name: Bestial Rend
entries: This discipline is often adopted by creatures with natural claws; {@race aarakocra|EEPC}, {@race tabaxi|VGM}, the {@race leonin|MOT} of Theros, and the {@race shifter|ERLW|shifters} peoples of Eberron. Your unarmed strikes deal slashing damage and inflict deep wounds in your target. Each time you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, its movement speed is reduced by 5 feet until the start of your next turn. If you reduce a creature's speed to 0, they are {@condition restrained} until the beginning of your next turn.

entries.name: Ungulate Charge
entries: This discipline is often adopted by creatures with hooves or horns; {@race centaurs|MOT}, {@race minotaurs|MOT}, or the {@race satyrs|MOT} of Theros. Once per turn, when you move at least 20 feet and hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can use a bonus action to force the creature to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, they are knocked {@condition prone} and take bludgeoning damage equal to your monk level.

entries.name: Reptilian Defense
entries: This discipline is often adopted by creatures with natural defenses, like the scaled {@race lizardfolk|VGM} or {@race tortle|TTP|tortles} with their protective shell. When fighting you position yourself to more easily defend against your foes. The last creature you hit with an unarmed strike on your turn has disadvantage on any attack rolls they make against you until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Intuition
entries: You have worked to master your instinctual abilities along with your physical form. At 6th level you gain proficiency in either {@skill Insight}, {@skill Perception}, or {@skill Survival}. In addition, whenever you make an {@skill Insight}, {@skill Perception}, or {@skill Survival} check you can expend 1 ki point to grant yourself advantage on the roll.

subclassFeature.name: Feral Strikes
entries: In your training you have learned to augment your physical strikes with the power of ki. Starting at 11th level, when you hit a creature with an unarmed strike you can expend 1 ki point to increase the damage of your unarmed strike by {@dice 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Apex Predator
entries: Upon reaching 17th level, you have mastered your physical form and brought forth its wild potential. You learn one of the following disciplines of your choice.

entries.name: Bestial Fury
entries: You can whip yourself into a primal fury when hunting your foes. When you score a critical hit against a creature with an unarmed strike, its speed is reduced to 0, and you have advantage on any unarmed strikes you make against that creature until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Ungulate Trample
entries: You can draw upon primal speed to trample those in your path. As an action, you can expend 4 ki points and move up to your full movement speed in a straight line. Any creatures you pass through must make a Dexterity saving throw or take {@dice 8d6} bludgeoning damage and fall {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Reptilian Resilience
entries: You can harden your exterior to deflect incoming blows. As a reaction when you are hit by an attack, you can expend ki to increase your Armor Class until the start of your next turn. For each ki point you expend your Armor Class increases by 2, up to a maximum of 5 ki points.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Sacred Ink
entries: Those who seek to master the Way of the Sacred Ink spend years practicing the calligraphy of their sacred rite. Once they are ready, the monks mark their bodies with increasingly complex celestial tattoos, granting them access to small amounts divine power. As the monk's spiritual connection to the divine grows, so does the beauty of their celestial tattoos. Monks of this Sacred Tradition usually travel the world, supporting those who treasure beauty and light, and using their divine power to smite those who stand against them.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Artist
entries: When you adopt this Monastic Tradition at 3rd level your training pays off, and you master the techniques necessary to become a monk of the sacred ink. You gain proficiency with {@item calligrapher's supplies|phb}, and add double your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make with these tools.
In addition, you can speak, read, and write Celestial.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Conduit
entries: Your Celestial tattoos allow you to channel the radiant power of the upper planes through your hands. You can perform a short meditation to align yourself with an aspect of the upper planes. At the end of a short or long rest, choose one of the following abilities, which lasts until the end of your next rest.

entries.name: Divine Shield
entries: You can channel ki through your sacred tattoos shield you from harm. As a bonus action you can grant yourself temporary hit points equal to your monk level. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once) at no cost. After which, you must expend 1 ki point to use this ability again.

entries.name: Healing Touch
entries: You channel ki through your sacred tattoos to heal. As an action, you can restore {@dice 1d8} hit points to a creature you touch. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once) at no cost. After which, you must expend 1 ki point to use this ability again. This feature has no effect on constructs or undead.

entries.name: Radiant Strike
entries: You channel ki through your sacred tattoos to smite your enemies. When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can choose to deal an extra {@dice 2d6} radiant damage to the target. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once) at no cost. After which, you must expend 2 ki points to use this ability again.

subclassFeature.name: Heavenly Protection
entries: Upon reaching 6th level, your connection to the divine, and the complexity of your celestial tattoos has grown, allowing you to protect yourself from death. You can cast {@spell death ward}, targeting only yourself, without expending a spell slot.
Once you cast {@spell death ward} in this way you must finish a short or long rest before you can cast it in this way again.

subclassFeature.name: Light of the Heavens
entries: Your sacred tattoos can provide a glimpse of the divine. Starting at 11th level, you can cause your celestial tattoos to emit the light of the upper planes. As a bonus action, you can emit bright sunlight in a 10-foot radius. While this feature is active, you add your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) to any temporary hit points you grant, hit points you restore, or damage you deal using your Divine Conduit features.
This feature lasts for 1 minute unless you end it as a bonus action or fall {@condition unconscious}. Once you use this feature you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Aspect
entries: You have become a master of the Sacred Ink, and the divine art that covers your body is a direct reflection of otherworldly beauty. Starting at 17th level, you can use an action to briefly assume a celestial form. For the next minute you gain the following benefits:

items: Your celestial tattoos manifest angelic wings. You gain a flying speed equal to your movement speed.
Your unarmed strikes deal radiant damage in place of the normal bludgeoning damage.
Your attacks deal an additional {@dice 1d6} radiant damage on hit.
You gain access to all three abilities from your Divine Conduit feature for the duration.

entries: Once you use this feature you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.
